The Weekly Newsquiz tests students' knowledge of events in the news.
Missao Okawa died Wednesday morning in Osaka, Japan. She left behind three children, four grandchildren and six great grandchildren.
Documents show Missouri National Guard used highly militarized words to describe protesters. The language is intensifying the concerns of some who objected to police officers' actions.
Two suicide bombers detonate their car at the entrance of the building. Five gunmen then enter the building, shooting people inside. Somali special forces battled the gunmen inside.
Gregory Margolin, 87, was a Jewish recruit in the Soviet Red Army. He fought the Nazis in World War II and rose to be a commander in the army. He suffers from Alzheimer's disease, a degenerative condition that impairs memory.
More than 200 schoolgirls were abducted from their dormitories in northeastern Nigeria. A year on, CNN's Chris Brown is marking the grim 12-month milestone of the girls' disappearance. He says the world should all feel shame: shame that lives of young girls can be shattered with impunity by fanatical thugs.
Norway is slated to become the first country to phase out radio entirely. Half the country already listens digitally.
A new study suggests the Brontosaurus belongs to its own genera. The study took five years and included visits to 20 museums in Europe and the U.S.
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula offers the reward for the death or capture of two prominent Shia Muslim opponents. Converted to currency, the gold reward would be worth about $774,000.

Scores of dead fish appear in the Rodrigo de Freitas lagoon in Rio de Janeiro. Officials believe recent rains caused a temperature change and excess of decaying organic matter. Rio de Janeiro has pledged to reduce pollution in the notoriously fetid bay.
Anthony Ray Hinton was convicted of killing two men in 1985. He was sentenced to death. A new trial was ordered in 2014 after experts said the revolver Hinton was said to have used couldn't be matched to other evidence.

The Glass House in Chislehurst was built for government officials in the event of a nuclear winter in 1951. The building was chosen because the wooden area surrounding the building afforded it secrecy. It fell into disrepair in the years following the end of the Cold War but has now been transformed into a luxury home. The property also boasts a swimming pool, a stunning atrium and a magnificent glass staircase.

Peter Alliss, 84, claims equality laws have 'b*****ed up the game' He claims legislation designed to stop golf clubs from discriminating against female members has instead prompted a decline in women’s membership. Some clubs had previously only allowed female members if they played at restricted times in return for a discounted membership fee. But the Equality Act 2010, drafted by the previous Labour government, ruled that this was illegal discrimination.

Researchers at Brown University in Rhode Island tested the ability of nine frequent gamers against a control group of people who game rarely. They found that gaming improved the ability to learn visual tasks. But the researchers are not quite sure if gaming makes people learn skills better - or if people who learn skills better are more likely to become gamers.

Riff lets you film videos and upload them to Facebook and the app. Friends and strangers can then film relevant clips and attach them to the end of your video to create a collaborative project. It was created by London-based developers through Facebook's Creative Labs. Each video has a counter that shows how many clips are attached, and which clip in the sequence the viewer is currently watching. Individual clips can be reported for inappropriate content, for example, by clicking the menu button in the top right-hand corner of a clip and clicking the red whistle icon.

A survey has shown that for the fourth year in a row, Australians pay higher prices for a range of consumer goods and services than are paid in any other place. The survey uses the purchasing power parity index to determine the relative price levels to the US dollar. It found that Australian prices are at 112 per cent of the US, meaning that we pay $1.12 to every $US1.

YouTube user Elman511 cracked open an over-sized egg that was laid by one of his hens. He found a standard-sized egg inside, along with yolk and white inside. The unusual occurrence is down to a counter-peristalsis contraction. This is when a second oocyte is released by the hen's ovary before the first egg has completely traveled through the oviduct and been laid. The hen's ovary then contracts, forcing the first egg to reverse its course. The second oocyte is released too

Both men are expected to survive any injuries.

University of South Florida Institute of Anthropology and Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office have proposed building a 'body farm' in Lithia. Five to ten bodies from USF's After Life Body Donation Program would be buried or placed on two acres of land. Hillsborough County Commissioner Stacy White has taken a stand against the facility, fearing strong odors and the reputation it could bring to his community. Research could help solve more than 500 cold cases in Hillsborough, Pasco and Pinellas counties.

Suddenly he begins panicking and while not visible to the camera, a minor avalanche occurs behind him. The skier can be seen falling to the floor as heavy snow closes in around him and in a matter of moments he is completely submerged.

Australian Rugby Union has passed a new policy to allow experienced players playing overseas to be selected for Australia. Players with 60 caps who have held professional contract with Australian Rugby for at least seven years will be eligible. Other players based abroad will immediately become eligible if they commit to playing Super Rugby in Australia for the following two seasons. Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who both play for Toulon, as well as flanker George Smith, who also plays in France, would immediately qualify to play at the World Cup later this year.

New footage shows twisting groups of magnetic fields writhing around a central axis before bursting from the sun. The flux rope is the main cause of several types of solar weather - including solar flares and coronal mass ejections. The footage was revealed in a paper in Nature Communications led by Dr Haimin Wang from the New Jersey Institute of Technology.

Audi claims to have created the fuel of the future - diesel made from water and carbon dioxide. Experts used renewable energy to convert the carbon dioxide and water into a form of crude oil known as 'blue crude' This was then refined into diesel. Tests have shown it can be mixed with diesel from fossil fuels, or used as a fuel in its own right. The breakthrough was developed by Audi along with Sunfire, a Dresden-based energy technology company.

Researchers subjected Lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries to external heat. They then used thermal imaging and non-invasive high speed imaging techniques to observe changes in their internal structure. Copper inside the battery reached temperatures of at least 1,085°C (1,985°F) and it caused molten material to stream from its vent. The footage is the first time the failure of Li-ion batteries due to overheating has been recorded.

Nasa has been testing a flexible wing on a plane in California. The wing can bend from -2 degrees up to 30 degrees. It means that regular flaps aren't needed - and it is much lighter. The wing is able to ‘bend’ through angles from -2 degrees up to 30 degrees. Test pilots have described it as being ‘very smooth’ and ‘very smooth’ It could also increase fuel efficiency up to 12 per cent, and reduce noise at take-off and landing up to 40 per cent.

Scientists at Haverford College in Pennsylvania, US, used Nasa's NuStar telescope to capture the image. They found an emission of X-rays that corresponded to thousands of dead stars being present. The dead stars are thought to be leaving a'mass grave' of white dwarf stars near the centre of the Milky Way galaxy. But why there are so many of these stars here remains a mystery.

The Bruno Smartcan is said to be the first internet connected combined kitchen bin and vacuum cleaner. It uses sensors to detect when dust is swept towards it and activates its integrated vacuum. Bruno comes with an integrated bag dispenser that additionally sends alerts to a smartphone when the owner is getting low on bags. It looks at the composition of Iron Man's suit - said to be a gold-titanium alloy in one of the movies - and Captain America's shield. Some owners of the Apple Watch have found the watch’s sensors malfunction if worn on tattooed wrists. Some dark, vibrant ink seems to cause the watch’s heart rate monitor to lose connection and give inaccurate readings. This is because the heart sensor reads a pulse by measuring light absorption through the skin. Tests suggest tattoos in dark and solid colours interfere with the watch the most. Apple has yet to comment on the apparent fault, despite speculation that the apparent fault could also stop some people using Apple Pay.
Automated Planet Finder (APF) consists of a 2.4-metre automated telescope and a high-resolution spectrograph. It splits starlight into a spectrum of thousands of different wavelengths. The spectrograph enables astronomers to detect the tiny wobble induced in a star by the gravitational tug of an orbiting planet. The ultimate goal of extrasolar planet research is to find planets like Earth that might support life in other solar systems.
David Beckham is expected to fly out to Morocco for a glamorous bash. He is said to be staying at the five-star luxury Amanjena resort. Tom Cruise, Guy Ritchie, Gordon Ramsay and Dave Gardner are set to attend.
Named Hyperion, the moon's porous surface can be seen in incredible detail in this image taken by Cassini as it performed a flyby of the satellite. The moon is 255 by 161 miles (410 by 260km) and is one of the largest bodies in the solar system known to be so irregular. It appears that Hyperion's surface becomes electrostatically charged as it is bathed in charged particles.
One man moved seats on Oman Air flight 102 to Muscat. Another passenger objected to the man and a row broke out. One man threw punches at the other, and also used his shoe as a weapon. One man was taken away for questioning by police after landing.

The proposed £30million, three-year contract for an Emirates FA Cup reveals the FA's resources to ensure the monies received by the clubs for progressing in the world's most famous club knockout tournament. The figures range from £1,150 for winning the extra preliminary round through to the £1.8million either Aston Villa or Arsenal will receive for lifting the trophy.

There will be three different routes through the site, and time limits imposed.

The USA Freedom Act would codify President Barack Obama's proposal to end the NSA's collection of domestic calling records. The authority to collect those records and other related surveillance provisions of the Patriot Act will expire June 1 unless Congress passes a law reauthorizing it. Similar legislation was introduced in the U.S. Senate by Democrat Patrick Leahy and Republican Mike Lee. But Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is seemingly out of phase, sponsoring his own bill to extend the PATRIOT Act until the end of 2020.
Angelika Graswald, 35, has been charged with second-degree murder in the death of her fiance Vincent Viafore, 46. Viafore was kayaking with Graswald on the Hudson River April 19 when his vessel flipped over near Cornwall-On-Hudson. Graswald called 911 telling the dispatcher she had fallen out of her own kayak. She was later picked up by a boater. Police have yet to find Viafore's body.

Fossils from an extinct pygmy sperm whale that died seven million years ago, have shed new light on the evolution of modern day whales. The well-preserved skulls of two individuals were unearthed at a sea cliff along the Caribbean coast of Panama. They indicate that the organ involved in sound generation and echolocation got smaller throughout the whale’s evolution.
Nasa has released an image taken by the probe's Visual and Infrared Spectrometer (Virs) The images reveal distinct features such as volcanic vents and fresh craters. To highlight the geological features, the images have been overlain on a black and white mosaic from the Mercury Dual Imaging System (MDIS) The event will take place on Thursday 30 April at 3:30pm Eastern Time (7.30pm GMT)

Scientists from the University of Connecticut say animals are most at risk in South America, Australia, and New Zealand. They claim the rate of extinction will speed up in line with rising temperatures. If future temperatures increase by only two degrees compared to pre-industrial levels, the extinction risk would increase from 2.8 to 5.2%. But if global warming maintains its current trajectory and a 4.3 degree increase, that could increase to 16%.
When people search for the aubergine, or eggplant, hashtag no posts appear. It is believed the emoji is commonly used to represent male genitalia. It is believed the emoji may be attached to images containing nudity. Instagram told MailOnline it is not commenting on the anomaly.

Nancy Perry will no longer teach students at Dublin Middle School in Georgia and will retire at the end of the year. Perry is alleged to have told students that Obama is a Muslim and that any parent who support him couldn't be Christian, either. A 12-year-old boy in Perry's class brought the matter to the attention of his father, Jimmie Scott, who complained to the school. Scott said he immediately requested a parent-teacher conference to which Perry brought along her husband Bill, who sits on the county Board of Education.

Researchers took thermal infrared photographs of 41 volunteers’ faces. They then used artificial neural networks to compare the sober and drunken images. The algorithm can determine a person’s state of intoxication by looking at the temperature of their face - especially the forehead and nose. And they say the technology could one day be installed in cars to spot drink drivers and stop them starting the ignition.

Pillars of Creation are one of the most iconic images ever taken by the Hubble Space Telescope. New observations, taken by European Space Agency, reveal many new details. Researchers from Nagoya University, Japan, studied stone tools from the Early Ahmarian culture and the Protoaurignacian culture. Earth's continents are slowly moving together, and in 50 to 200 million years they are expected to form a new supercontinent called Amasia. In 2012 a study suggested this may be centered on the North Pole. Recent evidence is revealing how this will compare to the ancient supercontinents Rodinia and Pangaea. The Indian plate is continuing to move North at a few centimetres per year - causing tectonic activity. But other continents are also moving towards each other.

Called Bodyprint, the technology turns a standard touchscreen into a biometric scanner removing the need to specialist hardware. Bolivia’s Cal Orcko paleontological site is the result of tectonic activity that forced the earth upwards. It is at Fancesa limestone quarry in Sucre, Bolivia, and comprises 462 trails made up of 5,055 prints. The wall, which is approximately 390 feet (120 metres) tall, features tracks made by at least eight species of dinosaurs.

US researchers claim that exact prices of goods on eBay attract higher offers. Items with precise prices attract higher offers than items with round numbers. Sellers who end their price with ‘00’ typically receive offers that are five to eight per cent lower than those with more specific prices.

The dinosaur, named Yi qi, means ‘strange wing’, may have been able to glide or even flap. Palaeontologists in China say the fossil belongs to a small dinosaur thought to have lived 160 million years ago. It had small stiff feathers on its body and long finger-like bones extending from each wrist that were covered in a membrane like a bat’s wing. The discovery has provided new insight into how vertebrates first began to take to the air.

Between 20 and 50 social media accounts active in Baltimore on Monday were also used some 825 miles away in Ferguson during last summer's violence. Astronomers have used a telescope in New Mexico to watch a star take shape over eight years. The images were taken by the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array in 1996 and 2014. The images show the outflow of material from the young star has dramatically expanded as it takes shape. The images were created by data from 27 radio telescope antennae in the New Mexico desert in the U.S.

Participants pray to a god who is said to help with fertility, child birth and protection from sexually transmitted infections. 'Marilyn Einstein' was created by superimposing a blurry picture of Monroe over a picture of Albert Einstein drawn in fine lines. Features with a high spatial frequency (Einstein) are only visible when you're viewing them close up, and those with low spatial frequencies (Monroe) are only visible from further away. Combining pictures of the two produces a single image which changes when the viewer moves closer or farther away from the screen.
A researcher says a 'bone flute' found in Slovenia is not an instrument. Instead, he says it is simply a bone chewed by a hyena with teeth marks. The Divje Babe Flute is often said to be the world’s oldest musical instrument. But new research suggests historians have been fooled by these phoney objects.

Pelvic organ prolapse occurs when tissue supporting pelvic organs weakens. Complications include discomfort during sex or stress incontinence. Many who suffer are offered just one solution: a hysterectomy. But a growing number of surgeons claim not enough women are offered the alternative.
Researchers from London and Edinburgh have developed a computer that can collate meteorological information and then produce forecasts. It uses a process known as 'natural language generation' (NLG) This process produces readable texts in English, or other languages, automatically on a computer. It has the potential to one day be used in humanoid robots on our TV screens.

The Hospital of Dolls, or Ospedale delle Bambole as it is known in Rome, was built by the Squatriti family 60 years ago. Today their descendants, Federico Squatriti, 52, and his 82-year-old mother Gelsomina continue the family tradition. The mother and son team painstakingly restores hundreds of toys - carefully mending the porcelain heads and re-attaching the limbs.

Scientists from Cambridge University and Oxford Brookes University say that modern humans may have carried diseases that killed off Neanderthals. They say diseases such as typhoid, whooping cough, encephalitis and the common cold may have killed them. They say modern humans may have also passed on the diseases to us. They say the diseases may have made us more vulnerable to cancer and diabetes.

DNA-like fragments may have come with 'instructions' that guided their growth. DNA fragments used their innate self-evolving abilities to grow into repeated chemical chains long enough to evolve into primitive life. Scientists at the University of Connecticut say we know how far away the source of a sound is by listening to the echoes it produces. They found that the reverberations of sound help us locate the distance of, for example, a car passing round a bend or a person nearby. The research was conducted by scientists from the University of Connecticut and published in the Journal of Neuroscience.

Woolly mammoths became extinct as a result of crippling bone disease. Deficiency resulted in them breaking their limbs and spines, and leaving them unable to walk. It meant the giant animal, which stood 10ft (three metres) high, eventually collapsed to the ground and could not forage for food, or flee hunters. Until now it was thought that the hairy beast simply died out from post-Ice Age climate change and being hunted to extinction by early man.

For the first time in 65 years the California Department of Water Resources has found no snow during its manual survey of the land at 6,800 feet in the Sierra Nevada in early April. The fourth consecutive year of vanishing snow spells trouble as California depends on it to melt into rivers and replenish reservoirs. The governor's order requires cities and towns to cut water use by 25 percent.

Researchers from Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology Graduate University in Japan compared the distribution of fairy circles to skin cells. They found that the majority of skin cells and fairy circles both had six 'neighbours', and similar percentages of cells. The pattern is similar to the distribution of fairy circles in the Namibian desert.

Researchers at Wisconsin University in Madison analysed gibbons' calls. They found gibbons produce a variety of soft call types, known as 'hoos' These calls are almost inaudible to the human ear. Predator 'hoos' were produced at frequencies well below the threshold of hearing for eagles and other birds of prey.

But the actual figure is actually only 2.5 times faster - 14.7 megabits per second. This compares to 5.9Mbit/s per second on the 3G service that most people use. The Red Lady's remains were found in the El Mirón Cave in Cantabria, Spain. Radiocarbon dating suggests she was buried 18,700 years ago. When the remains were first uncovered they were stained with a sparking red material, later found to be red ochre from a haematite crystal. She was 'robust, relatively tall, [and] apparently healthy', said the researchers.

The American Heart Association and federal government regulations have for decades warned that excess salt contributes to the deaths of tens of thousands of Americans each year. As the federal government prepares its influential Dietary Guidelines for 2015, some scientists are now saying that the average American salt consumption rate carries no risk. The guidelines currently dictate the people should limit their intake to 2,300 milligrams, with an even stricter 1,500 milligram limit for African Americans and people over 50.

Fergus Simpson from University of Barcelona applied a mathematical formula to assume aliens obey the same laws of conservation of energy as animals on Earth. This means larger animals need more resources to survive, so are less common than plentiful ants, for example. He claims there must be a minimum body size necessary for supporting intelligent life, based on the range of body sizes of intelligent animals such as apes and humans. If intelligent extraterrestrials exist they will typically weigh 650lbs (300kg)

As short waves collide near the surface they create weak microseismic waves. These waves combine with long waves dragging across the ocean's floor. This creates a constant hum that has been likened to the ring of a bell.

A 'human molecule' might contain 375 million atoms of hydrogen, 132 million atoms of oxygen and 85 million atoms of carbon. By comparison, this human molecule contains just one atom of cobalt and three molecules of the metal molybdenum.

Sunspots occur when a concentration of magnetic fields causes the surface temperature to reduce, making a specific section of the sun stand out. The phenomenon is fairly common and the number of spots on the solar surface reflects with how active the sun is. Sunspots range in size, from just 10 miles (16km) to 100,000 miles (160,000km) wide - big enough to be seen from Earth without a telescope.

The Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay' (MIND) diet includes at least three daily servings of wholegrains and salad. It also includes an extra vegetable and a glass of wine. The diet lowered the risk of Alzheimer's by 53 per cent in those who stuck to it rigidly. For those that followed it moderately well, it lowered the risk by about 35 per cent.

HIV specialists and network security experts at University College London created a model of HIV progression. They built a model which accurately predicted patients' progression from HIV to AIDS in a major clinical trial. Team noticed that the spread of HIV through the body using two methods - via the bloodstream and directly between cells - was similar to how some computer worms spread through the internet.

Ephedra foeminea waits for the full moon to 'bloom' and produces a sugary droplet to attract pollinating insects. The plant secretes the droplets at night to attract insects. When a butterfly or insect lands on the transparent orbs at night, the pollen it’s carrying is used to fertilise the seed. Researchers from Stockholm University noticed the droplets at the same time of the year having conducted four years of research.

Scientists at San Jose State University used a new technique to reconstrcut the colourful patterns on 28 fossilised cone snail shells. Shells are up to 6.6 million years old and are covered in streaks of orange, purple, blue and even large pokadots. The technique has allowed researchers to look millions of years into the past to see how these once elaborately decorated shells would have once looked.
Scientists funded by Cancer Research UK studied samples taken from tumours in the prostate and around the body in ten affected men. DNA revealed details of how the cancer metastasises, or spreads. Cells in a tumour stay where they are, but a small number travel through the body, creating new tumours as they go. These cells are the ‘root’ of the cancer and for a treatment to work, they should be destroyed.

The native Australian marsupial once occupied more than 70 per cent of the Australian mainland. It’s disappeared from around 80 per cent of that area with small populations remaining in Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Predators like feral cats and foxes are the biggest threat to the bilby populations. Predators like farm animals destroying bilby habitat and introduced species like rabbits competing with them for food and burrows.

Researchers in Massachusetts say a person's keystrokes may reveal a huge amount of information about their motor skills. They're working on creating a keyboard that can tell doctors if someone has the neuron impairment, simply by analysing the way they type. For instance, it can distinguish between typing done in the middle of the night, when sleep deprivation impairs motor skills, and typing performed when fully rested.

Ava Ciach, from Victoria, had a skull that was too small for her brain. She had Sagittal Synostosis - two plates at the front of her skull had fused together prematurely restricting the growth of her brain. A CT scan proved Ava had the condition, which is usually discovered when a child is between 10 months and two years old. She underwent a complex operation in which she had her skull removed, smashed into pieces and put back together like a jigsaw puzzle.

The RV Flip is a 355-foot scientific platform used by the US Office for Naval Research. It has been used for more than 50 years to study underwater acoustics. The vessel is towed to its location where it turns 90 degrees leaving just 50 feet above the surface. The flip is designed to keep the vessel in place so scientists can conduct experiments.

Greenstone is a small egg-shaped gadget that acts like a beacon or booster. It helps messages move around so-called wireless mesh networks more easily. It was created by Open Garden and uses Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework. MCF lets you send messages even when a person has no signal. It creates what’s called a wireless mesh network that connects phones.

One-Touch-911 app was created by developers at Boston-based MIT. It works with global emergency response teams to create a standard call. Each of the four buttons on the app trigger a standard call to dispatchers. Each call is placed with the phone's GPS location, user details and any pre-entered medical information attached. If the user doesn't have signal, the app lets them 'roam' onto another network to connect the call.
Corporal Mark Donaldson VC is one of Australia's most highly decorated soldiers. He is one of the very few to have been awarded the nation's highest military honour, the Victoria Cross, for his bravery in Afghanistan. Donaldson was a member of an elite Special Air Services unit ordered to assassinate a Taliban warlord who had boasted he would kill Prince Harry. Donaldson was awarded the VC for his actions in September 2008 when he ran 80 metres to rescue a wounded interpreter.

The ring, located 12 billion light years away, is an illusion created by the chance alignment of two distant galaxies. It is a rare manifestation of gravitational lensing predicted by Albert Einstein in his theory of general relativity.

Scientists believe the first complex conversation between humans took place around 50,000 to 100,000 years ago. Much of it, they believe, still involved cavemen grunting, or hunter-gatherers mumbling and pointing, before learning to speak in a detailed way. But in a new study, Shigeru Miyagawa, Professor of Linguistics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, says that human language likely developed rapidly. He says single words bear traces of syntax showing that they must be descended from an older, syntax-laden system, rather than from simple,

A University of Nebraska researcher has revealed why stress is bad for you. Limited periods of stress are good, as they release the hormone cortisol. This is useful in helping you recover from very tense situations. But too much will lower your immune system and make your bones fragile. The science of stress was explained in a video by Dr Raychelle Burks. She explains that prolonged stress can inhibit the immune system. She also explains that stress can also lead to weaker bones.

Thousands of bacteria colonies were discovered on notes and coins. Money was collected from students at the University of Surrey. It was submerged in agar - a substance that allows bacteria to grow. Then monitored for three to four days to see if bacteria were present. Most of the colourful blooms and spots of bacteria was found to be harmless. But money has been known to carry dangerous diseases in previous studies.

Misao Okawa, 117, died of heart failure on April 1 at her nursing home in Osaka, Japan. Born on March 5, 1898, the great-grandmother had lived through two World Wars, the invention of the television and the first successful powered aeroplane flight by the Wright Brothers. She was only fifth person ever recorded to reach the age of 117.

Rosetta launched into space in 2004 and entered orbit around 67P in August. It chased comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko through space for ten years. It then released the Philae lander from its grip to land on the comet. But when it first made contact with the surface it failed to fire harpoons that would have kept it attached to the comet's surface. This resulted in it bouncing to a distance of nine miles (14km) of the surface.

Researchers in Tokyo found that rats flatten their ears, narrow their eyes and puff up their cheeks when they are in pain. They wanted to find out whether the rodents do this as a reflex reaction, or to communicate their discomfort to others. They found that Long-Evans rats can read pain on other animal’s faces and use the information to makes decisions.

Hospitalizations from car crashes dropped 7 percent between 2003 and 20010 in the 45 states with texting bans. Researchers from Texas A&M School of Public Health found that hospitalizations dropped 7 percent between 2003 and 20010 in the states with no restrictions. Arizona, Texas, Montana, Missouri, and Oklahoma are the only five states in America that do not have texting at the wheel bans for all drivers.

Natalie Whitear, 35, has prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness. Condition means she is unable to recognise her own reflection or children. She was born with condition but was only diagnosed three years ago. She says she is able to describe weight, height, and hair colour of her family. But she can't recognise her husband or children's facial features in detail.
All elephants will be phased out of the Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus performance by 2018. The animals will be retired to the Ringling Brothers Elephant Conservation Center in Polk County, central Florida. The center's goal is to conserve the Asian Elephant, an animal whose population has decreased to between 25,000 and 32,000 over the last century.

Cheyenne Mountain was built to direct the American response to a nuclear war with the USSR during the Cold War. The complex was home to the North American Aerospace Command (NORAD) which scanned the skies for Russian missiles. The complex shut down nearly ten years ago as the threat from Russia seemed to subside. This week the Pentagon announced that Cheyenne Mountain will once again be home to the most advanced tracking and communications equipment in the United States military.
The 40 centimetre-long Philippine crocs flew out of Melbourne on Wednesday. They travelled in custom designed boxes specially built by Melbourne Zoo. The arrival of these one year olds is part of a major conservation effort. There are only about 250 Philippines crocodiles left in the wild.
Taken in Tokyo, the images show the work of Japan's 'lonely death' squads. They clean out the properties of elderly people who die alone and go unnoticed by their families. Thankfully, police officers will have already removed the often badly decomposed bodies before the cleaning teams arrive.
DNA analysis shows that hunter gatherers living in Spain up to 8,500 years ago still had dark skin. It was not until 7,800 years ago, when the first farmers migrated from the Near East through Turkey, that two genes that provide lighter skin appeared. Around 5,800 years ago the second gene, which makes skin colour lighter still, also began to spread through the European population.

The National Defense Reserve Fleet was set up in the wake of the Second World War in 1945. At its height in the 1950s, the fleet consisted of nearly 2,280 ships moored across the United States. Today, just over 120 ships remain, posing a risk to the environment in the bays where they are moored. The Maritime Administration has pledged to dismantle the fleet at Suisun Bay, with 25 ships in the worst condition taken out within two years.

Research led by the University of Montana found that during recovery periods between periods of exercise, it didn’t matter what food was eaten. Performance remained the same after resting for several hours. Levels of glycogen - used by muscles as ‘fuel’ - were actually slightly higher after fast food was eaten as a recovery food.

BAE System's Typhoon is so accurate that even the movements of the tide can disrupt the jet fighter's positioning and accuracy. Experts build the jet on 'floating' concrete rafts that move in sync with the moon. This helps its ‘fly by wire’ computer system to accurately control the aircraft. Typhoon can take off in less than 8 seconds, achieve supersonic speeds in under 30 seconds and reach altitudes of 36,000 feet Mach 1.6 in under two and a half minutes.
Children who ate a diet higher in saturated fats and cholesterol had slower reaction times and a poorer working memory. Scientists at the University of Illinois recruited 150 children aged between seven and 10 and gave them a task-switching game to complete. They found that after five days of eating lots of fat, the muscles' ability to oxidise glucose was disrupted. This could lead to long-term problems such as weight gain, obsesity and other health problems.

All U.S. Embassy staff were accounted for and returned safely to their mission, the embassy said. The motive for the attack was not immediately known.

The technician or technicians involved worked for a University of Utah Hospital clinic that provides dialysis for the prison.

Daspletosaurus, a relative of Tyrannosaurs, may have indulged in cannibalism. Scientists found bite marks on the skull of a juvenile 75 million years ago. Some of the injuries appear to have been sustained during combat. Others appear to have occurred after death, causing the animal to eat it.
Len Barnes, 75, from Stockton, was suffering from the life-threatening condition Clostridium difficile. He lost his appetite and endured continuous pain. Specialists suggested a faecal transplant to fight the infection. His daughter Debbie acted as donor and he was admitted to hospital. He was given a solution mixed with a healthy person's poo and water. The solution was then injected into Mr Barnes' bowel via an endoscope. Mr Barnes was then discharged from hospital and was cured the infection.

The remains of a woman nicknamed The Red Lady of El Mirón were discovered in 2010 in the El Mirón Cave in Cantabria. They were entombed in an elaborate grave and were stained in red paint. Researchers found spores of several mushroom species embedded in the plaque. This is the oldest evidence yet that early humans ate mushrooms.

National Institute on Drug Abuse in the US has admitted that the drug offers benefits to some cancer patients. Currently the drug is not recognised by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as a medicine. But studies of the chemicals in marijuana have led the FDA to approve two medications that contain cannabinoids. THC increases appetite and reduces nausea. It may also decrease pain, inflammation and muscle control problems. CBD is a cannabinoid that does not affect the mind or behaviour.

Scientists at UCLA examined the brains of 90 women. Found the lateral orbitofrontal cortex and the posterior cigulate cortex were thinner in those women taking the Pill. The lateral orbitofrontal cortex plays an important role in regulating a person's emotions and their response to rewards. The posterior cingulate cortex governs the 'internal state', or inward-directed thought, helps process emotions and retrieve memories.

Scientists at Rockefeller University in New York have developed an antibody that blocks the key viral protein receptor that is needed to infect human blood cells. The antibody was injected into patients and resulted in a 300-fold reduction in the amount of HIV in their blood. Scientists believe the discovery could pave the way for a new HIV vaccine.

Geologist Dr Danny Hilman believes that a site in West Java is revered because it hides an ancient temple built between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago. The megalithic site of Gunung Padang was discovered in 1914 and is the largest site of its kind in Indonesia. If the structure is revealed to be a 20,000-year-old pyramid, it will be the oldest on Earth. If true, the claim could rewrite prehistory in the region and shed light on an obscure yet powerful and advanced ancient civilisation.

Coles has been ordered to pay $2.5 million in penalties after lying to shoppers about the freshness of its bread. The Federal Court deemed the supermarket giant misleading by claiming its bread was baked on the day it is sold. Coles has received a three-year ban to no longer promote its bread as baked on the day it is sold. The falsely labelled bread has generated an income of about $300 million for Coles over three years.

Disused Rhondda Tunnel, which runs 1,000 feet beneath Welsh hills, was closed 50 years ago. It was closed as part of the Beeching Report, which spelled end for thousands of stations across rail network in Britain. But engineers are due to visit the 3,148m tunnel next week - for the first time since it closed - to see whether it is safe to use as a cycle route.

The 'yes means yes' law defines consent as 'affirmative, conscious, and voluntary agreement to engage in sexual activity' from each partner. Dr Lara Briden says severe symptoms such as nausea, back or leg pain can all point to a more serious condition - endrometriosis. Endometriosis is a condition where bits of the uterus lining grow outside of the uterus such as the ovaries, bladder or intestines. $250 (£168) device recognises the electronic signature of different devices. This allows users to keep an eye on their energy consumption and even control appliances through their phone. The sensors are plugged into the house’s breaker panel, or circuit box. They measure both differential voltage and current signals every split second and these signals are used to calculate power and energy consumption. Neurio feeds information about energy consumption of the devices it’s recognised back to an app, where users can make decisions about how to save power and money.

This suggests it interacts with itself - making detection of dark matter difficult. Dark matter accounts for 85% of the universe’s mass. Kenton Lee, from Nampa, Idaho, came up with the idea while working in Kenya. He came up with the idea after seeing children running around barefoot. Pressure sensors in the shoe tell it when your foot is in position. A motor in the heel pulls the laces tight when your foot is in position. The Michigan Micro Mote is the smallest computer in the world. It contains solar cells that power the battery with ambient light. This allows the computers to run perpetually. It is the first complete, operational computer system measuring as small as 2mm.

Ice is not just at the Martian poles, but likely towards the equator as well. This means that, if all ice were to be spread across the surface of Mars, the entire planet would be covered in more than 3.3ft (one metre) of ice. The study was carried out by scientists at the Niels Bohr Institute at the University of Copenhagen.

Gruesome death rituals performed 1,200 years ago have been uncovered in dozens of tombs in Peru's Cotahuasi Valley. Each tomb was filled with bones of up to 60 mummies, with infants kept in small containers, and others repeatedly ripped to pieces while decomposing. Archaeologists have so far opened up seven of the tombs, recovering 171 broken mummies from the ancient ceremonial site known as Tenahaha.

There were at least three reports of people trying to release gopher tortoises in the ocean because they were mistaken for sea turtles. According to the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission, all five species of sea turtle and the gopher turtle nest in the sand. Gopher tortoises have toes with claws on each toe and sea turtles have flippers with just one or two claws present on each fore flipper.

The creature, named Hyalinobatrachium dianae, was found in eastern Costa Rica. Most of its body is a brilliant lime green, like all species of glass frogs. Skin on its underside is see-though, making its organs easily visible. The frog’s heart, liver and gastrointestinal tract are easily visible.

More than 700 Asiatic black bears have allegedly been butchered in Vietnam. Farmers claim the animals are dying from disease and old age. But sources say owners are killing them to 'extract the last ounce of blood' Their paws, meat and gall bladders are sold for £625 a bear. The paws, meat and gall bladders are used in traditional Chinese medicine.
Many Californians are using techniques that utilize so-called 'gray water' to help them meet the unprecedented new water-use restrictions imposed by Governor Jerry Brown last week. The techniques may seem weird to some - like the toilet that doubles as a sink and used washing machine water to water fruit trees.
Emma Hannigan was told in 2005 she carried the faulty BRCA1 gene. This increases a woman's chance of getting breast cancer by 85 per cent. She had a double mastectomy and oophorectomy in 2006 to reduce risk. But a year later she was told she had breast cancer and had four bouts. She has now battled the disease nine times, including four in a year.

Divers from the Smithsonian Institution dredged up the artifacts from the ship. The artifacts will now go on display at the local museum.

Visual Health Studios in Colorado has developed a weight loss app called Visualize You. It calculates what you would look like if you lost a specified amount weight. Users are shown an original and a slimmer version, with a slider. The app costs £1.61 ($2.40) on Android and £1.49 ($1.99) on iOS.

New interactive map has revealed public opinion on global warming in all 50 states, 435 congressional districts and more than 3,000 counties. Gases used to send patients to sleep are accumulating in the Earth's atmosphere. Scientists say concentrations are low but they are warming the planet. Desflurane, isoflurane and sevoflurane have 2,500 times the impact on global warming compared to carbon dioxide.

Stocks of the influenza vaccine are arriving a month later than expected. Scientists have included protection against Influenza A strain H3N2 and Influenza B strain B/Phuket. The decision to include both was triggered by a spike in flu-related deaths in the northern hemisphere as the vaccine was not a good match to fight against the two types of flu. High-risk groups - such as the very young and very old, and most indigenous Australians - will be able to access free, government-funded flu shots from April 20.

Elon Musk pursued a sale of struggling electric-car company Tesla to Google in 2013, according to an excerpt of a new biography. Beset by technical problems on its flagship Model S, Tesla in early 2013 was on the verge of bankruptcy. In March 2013, Musk contacted Google co-founder Larry Page, according to the excerpt. He proposed that Google buy Tesla for $6 billion and promise an additional $5 billion in factory expansions. He also demanded that he be permitted to run Tesla as a unit of Google for eight years, or until Tesla produced a third-generation car
Professor Eric Cline claims the Bronze Age civilisations were hit by disasters. He claims they were hit by a series of droughts, famines, climate change, earthquakes, invasions and internal rebellions between 1225BC and 1177 BC. He says each of the great societies were interconnected, the collapse of one also affected the others.

A new report from Suncorp Bank suggests Australian's have spent 50 per cent more on digital devices than they planned in the last year. Striking photographs show a shoal of fish making way for a blacktip shark in the shallow waters of Heron Island in Queensland, Australia. It is thought that the reef shark was not interested in catching a meal, but the fish naturally keep their distance, creating circles of clear water around the predator. Fish are thought to gain many benefits from shoaling behaviour, such as keeping safe from predators as well as boosting their chances of feeding.

The vaccine is made from pieces of a protein called TARP. It's found in about 95 per cent of prostate cancers. It's designed to teach the immune system to recognise compounds in cancer cells. It is being given to men who have already been treated for the cancer.

Senior Constable Neale McShane has spent ten years as an officer in Birdsville, in far south-west Queensland. The harsh region borders on the Simpson Desert, giving rise to a number of desert rescues that McShane must execute every year. The 59-year-old has spent 40 years as an officer in three different states, but he said nothing compares to the immense heat and desolate conditions of patrolling Birdsville. McShane said the unpredictable conditions of the job means his successor will need to be a fast learner.

The actress and Willis purchased the penthouse in 1990 from Saturday Night Fever producer Robert Stigwood. The 14-bedroom apartment includes a 7,000 square feet of living space and wrap around terraces with views of Central Park and the Hudson River. If it sells for that much, it will break the record for the most expensive co-op ever sold on the Upper West Side in history.

Solar Probe Plus will carry four instruments into the sun’s corona. It will study the solar wind and energetic particles as they blast off the surface of the star. During the closest passes around the sun, temperatures will reach nearly 2,500 degrees Fahrenheit. The mission will launch on a United Launch Alliance Delta 4-Heavy rocket with an upper stage from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida.
Kuku Kube is available for free on Facebook, Android, iOS and on desktop browsers. On each board, one of the squares is a slightly different shade of the same colour. Aim is to find this odd square by tapping it with your finger or clicking it. Players get just 60 seconds to find the odd square on each board before the timer runs out and the game ends.

Researchers have released an interactive roadkill map to show the trail of destruction being caused by California's state highways. The map uses data from the California Roadkill Observation System, a volunteer-submitted database of instances where wildlife and vehicles collided. Clicking on the dots reveals the species - striped skunk, mountain lion, black bear, gopher snake, desert iguana - and where and when they were hit.

Raul Castro, Arizona's only Hispanic governor, has died at age 98. Castro passed away on Friday morning while in his sleep in San Diego where he was in hospice care, family spokesman James Garcia said. He was a self-made man, the embodiment of the American dream overcoming poverty and discrimination to graduate from college, and launch a successful career in politics and diplomacy. During his career, Castro also served as an American ambassador to three countries including El Salvador, Bolivia and Argentina.

Researchers sequenced the microbiomes of Yanomami people living in a remote Amazon village in Venezuela. They found that Yanomami people harbor microbiomes with the highest diversity of bacteria and genetic functions ever reported in a human group. The bacteria they found could be potentially beneficial to modern society.

A Washington, DC-based company called United Space Structures wants to create a new space station. Their giant cylinder could apparently replace the ISS. It would rotate four times per minute to create artificial gravity, and would be 1,300ft (400 metres) long, cost £200 billion ($300 billion) and take 30 years to build. The dome-shaped design would house the command centre for the station, and also many of the supplies needed for the crew. The team says they have a patent for the'space mushroom'

Scientists in California have described how to create artificial auroras on Earth. They said a particle accelerator could be sent 185 miles (300km) up into space. It would then fire high-energy beams back at Earth's atmosphere. The beam would be triggered by a magnetic field in the atmosphere. This would create a beam of particles 0.5 to 10 million electron volts. The researchers say the machine could also create lightning.

Filmmaker Michael König from Cologne, Germany has created an amazing video showing solar activity. It was made by stitching together footage from Nasa's Solar Dynamics Observatory over five years. Highlights include plasma raining down on the sun, an extreme solar eruption and even a comet breezing through the sun’s atmosphere. The movie, called Sun, was created by filmmaker Michael König from Cologne. It uses footage recorded by Nasa’s Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) spacecraft between 2011 and 2015.

The '#kyliejennerchallenge' involves participants placing their mouth over the opening of a cup, jar or shot glass and sucking in until the air vacuum causes their lips to swell up. Countless teens, both boys and girls, have been sharing the disturbing results of their experiments on Twitter and Instagram. The method works by way of the airlock created in the opening of the glass or jar, which increases blood flow to the lips and causes them to swell.

Three studies have provided different theories for what happened after Earth was struck by a Mars-sized object called Theia, 4.45 billion years ago. What is agreed on, though, is that the impact actually happened. This is known as the giant impact hypothesis. It is based on the theory that Theia was similar to Earth. And another theory says the impact created a cloud of debris that mixed thoroughly with the Earth and then condensed to form the moon.

Lack of bacteria in the gut means we are less equipped to deal with germs. Our bodies often overreact when we come into contact with bugs, dust or pollen, according to the ‘hygiene hypothesis’ Many scientists believe that modern society, with its mania for sanitation and easy access to antibiotics, makes us hypersensitive to harmless allergens.

An Australian government report suggests that carbon dioxide produced by burning fossil fuels could be captured and used to produce the fizz in Cola. Many nations are looking into Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) technologies as a way to cut their greenhouse house emissions, of which carbon dioxide plays a large role. The technology has the potential to reduce the emissions of a typical coal-power plant by up to 90 per cent. But there are concerns over storing such huge amounts of carbon underground.

Queen Victoria spent her holidays at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight. She would travel to Portsmouth by train and then by ferry to Ryde. The nearest station was at Wootton, more than two miles from the property. In 1875, a station was built at Whippingham, the closest point on the line. Accommodation was built for the stationmaster, as well as waiting rooms. The building is now a five-bedroom family home, on the market for £625,000.

The bone was found during excavations ahead of a new pipeline in Essex. It is thought to date to 5,600 BC and was placed into a pit with a diameter of three feet. Three radiocarbon dates, two from bone fragments and one from charcoal, have confirmed the remains are around 7,614 years old. The find sheds light on early human society in Mesolithic Britain, when people were nomadic hunter gatherers before the arrival of farming.

Tracks were left by barefooted early human 1.5 million years ago. 99 prints found in Ileret, northwest Kenya, are oldest in the world. They belong to groups who all passed over the soft mud at the same time. This suggests that Homo erectus hunted for larger prey.

Sun-less planets could still harbour extra-terrestrial life, say astronomers. This is according to Sean Raymond, an astrophysicist with the Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Bordeaux in France. A planet needs to keep warm for liquid water to form, and without the sun, this heat would have to come from its interior. Globulettes - regions of dust and gas that can form planets - could make rogue more common than first thought.

Obese people appear to be protected against dementia, with a risk around 30% lower than those of a healthy weight. Findings contradict previous studies which suggested being fat – with a high Body Mass Index (BMI) - could raise the risk.

Last month's average temperature soared to 56.4°F (13.6°C) This was the highest for March in the 1880–2015 record, surpassing the previous record of 2010 by 0.09°F (0.05°C) The data, released today by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), takes into account global averages across land and sea surfaces. It follows earlier announcements from US government scientists that 2014 was the hottest year in modern history.

Sonnenspeicher uses a lithium iron phosphate battery to store energy harnessed by solar panels. This energy can be used throughout the day, and any excess is stored for when the sun goes down. Rather than selling this excess electricity back to the grid, homeowners can then use their stored supply to power their home until the sun rises again.

Today is the 150th anniversary of Confederate General Robert E. Lee's surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia to Union forces. The surrender in Appomattox, Virginia, marked the beginning of the end of the American Civil War in 1865. Study found overweight people are less likely to develop dementia. Those with a BMI of 25 to 29 had 18 per cent lower risk of dementia. Being underweight increased the dementia risk by 39 per cent. Lead researcher said results are a'surprise' but no excuse to pile on pounds.

Norwich scientists have developed an adaptor for colour blindness. Eye2TV can be plugged into any HDMI port on a TV or a computer monitor. A remote control or app then adjusts the colour adjustment. It allows colour blind people to watch shows they otherwise couldn't. The team is seeking £100,000 ($150,000) of funding on Kickstarter.

Research analysed DNA from 21,566 men convicted of sex offences in Sweden. Found brothers of convicted sex offenders four to five times more likely to commit similar crimes than men in the general population. Only 2% of cases could this familial connection be explained by shared environmental factors. Genetic factors were also found to be stronger for child molestation (46%) than for adult rape (19%)

Palaeontologists at the University of Alberta examined a pair of fossils found in Mongolia, which were first described in 2001. One is a complete skeleton, while the other is missing the middle and end of its tail. They believe that the key differences between the sexes lie in bones near the base of the tail. They suggest that male oviraptors used long feathers on their tails to attract mates, much like modern peacocks.

People with rapid eye movement sleep behaviour disorder (RBD) move around in their sleep and 'act out' their dreams. Up to 90 per cent of people with the condition will develop a neurological condition. People with RBD describe vivid dreams, and they act them out theatrically. They can be fighting enemies, or fleeing danger, and act out these dreams. This can range from making small hand movements to thrashing around.

A bell was rung from the top of the city's temple, while the drums were struck 34 times, one for each of China's provinces.

Map shows average yearly counts of lightning flashes per square kilometre. It was created using data from Nasa’s Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission satellite. The map shows areas with the largest number of flashes are shown in pink. The areas with the least are grey and purple, and the most occur in the far eastern Democratic Republic of Congo and Lake Maracaibo in northwestern Venezuela.

Images show two mysterious spots on dwarf planet Ceres with different thermal properties. Spots are named feature 1 and feature 5, and show up in visible light as bright flashes in comparison to rest of the dwarf planet's surface. In infrared, region 1 is cooler than rest of surface, but 5 is located in a region that is similar in temperature to surroundings. Images were captured by the Dawn probe from 28,000 miles (45,000km) away.

Scientists in China have introduced DNA changes to reproductive cells. This means any changes made will be carried on into future generations. New information from Nasa's Mars rover Curiosity has been published in the journal Nature. It suggests that there is liquid water close to the surface of the red planet. The substance perchlorate has been found in the soil, which lowers the freezing point so the water does not freeze into ice, but is liquid and present in very salty water.

A Pain and Gain report released by CoreLogic for the December quarter has revealed that home resales recording a gross loss were at an all time low. Only 8.6 percent of homes had recorded a loss and a shocking 32.3 percent had shown properties selling for more than double their original price. The total value of these profit making resales was over $17 billion, three and a half times more than the total of the loss-making resales at only $418 million. Sydney recorded the lowest loss-making resales at just 2.4 percent over the quarter

The new map allows astronomers to'stand' on planetary surfaces. It could help explain how water and lava once flowed across the red planet. The first mosaic, pieced together by the German Aerospace Center (DLR), comprises 1.4 million square miles (2.3 million square km) of the surface. It covers the vast crater-strewn highland region of the red planet. The mosaics were created using a high resolution stereo camera on Mars Express.

A University of Cologne scientist led research proposing a new theory. It suggests temperatures at Earth's equator were -40°C (-40°F) 2.4 billion years ago. The reasons why the whole planet was frozen are not understood. But it could have implications for finding life on frozen moons like Europa. This could also explain how the ice crust on Earth formed. The question, 'So when is Cheryl’s birthday?' was one of 25 questions set in the Singapore and Asian Schools Math Olympiad. It was designed for 14-year-olds who wanted to know when Cheryl's birthday was. Cheryl gives them a list of 10 possible dates: May 15, May 16, May 19. June 17, June 18. July 14, July 16, July 16, August 14, August 15, August 15 and August 17. To reach the answer, it is possible to work through the information both men know to rule out nine of the dates in the question.
Goldman Sachs predicts population growth will slow to 1.25 per cent over the next three years due to low birth rates, high death rates and falling net migration. This is significantly lower than widely-used Australian Bureau of Statistics population predictions of between 1.7 and 1.8 per cent. This will create an oversupply and see property prices fall by between 5 and 10 per cent in markets where construction supply has been strong. Sydney will be one of the only markets not to be hit by an oversupply of housing in the next three years.

Stormy weather system known as an East Coast Low hasn't hit NSW this strong since 2007. It is characterised by gales or storm force winds that can damage buildings, fell trees and powerlines, cause powerful surf that can damage the coast and run ships aground. On Monday night 24 Sydney suburbs incurred 100mm of rainfall, with Blacktown hit hardest. An estimated 100,000 homes are without power on Tuesday morning across Sydney, the Central Coast and Hunter region.

Flow VR provides passengers with a virtual image of the horizon that mimics the movements of the aircraft. This can help to combat the conflict between information coming from a person's eyes and their sense of balance in the inner ear. It also presents travellers with high quality images of their destination that replicate the time of day to help them acclimatise to their new time zone.

Researchers from Goldsmiths University in London and Ohio State University studied more than 13,000 twins aged nine to 16 from six countries. They found that 40 to 50 per cent of the differences in children’s motivation to learn could be explained by their genetic inheritance from their parents. Genetics and non-shared-environment factors had the largest effect on the children’s motivation to learn. The shared environment had negligible impact on the children’s motivation to learn.

Swiss researchers measured the temperature of 'Hot Jupiter' HD 189733b. They found the temperature reaches up to 3,000°C in the atmosphere. And wind speeds are in excess of 620 miles per hour. The findings were made using a novel technique relying on sodium signals. They suggest we may soon have the opportunity to examine other distant worlds beyond the solar system.

However, scientists are still not able to explain what they are. Dawn will begin its first science orbit around Ceres on 23 April. US scientists have found a way to use corn husks and stalks to make cheap hydrogen fuel that doesn't pollute the environment like fossil fuels. The breakthrough could one day see the fuel being produced locally and drivers stopping to refuel their vehicles at roadside bioreactors. It’s previously only been possible to convert between 30 and 60 per cent of plant sugar into hydrogen, by using industrial catalysts or fermenting techniques.

The SS City of Cairo was travelling from Bombay to England in 1942. It was torpedoed 480 miles south of St Helena, taking 100 tons of rupees. It was long assumed that the ship's cargo, belonging to the UK Treasury, would be lost forever. But a British-led team used pioneering techniques to track down the ship. They recovered the coins from a record depth of 17,000ft - 4,500ft deeper than the Titanic.

UK researchers studied the asteroid impact 66 million years ago. They found the heat near the impact site in Mexico was not intense enough to ignite plant material. A heat pulse lasted less than a minute, too short to set plants alight. This suggests our understanding of the mass extinction event that wiped out the dinosaurs may not be as complete as thought.

Psychologists at New York University have been trying to gain an understanding about how the brain stores memories for 'emotionally neutral events' This is because emotion affects activity in brain regions involved in emotional processing - particularly the amygdala and striatum. In 84 days from November 2013 to January 2014, the area around Azle, Texas, shook with 27 magnitude two or greater earthquakes. Now scientists believe these earthquakes were the result of high-pressure injection of drilling wastewater into the ground. The oil and gas industry uses injection wells to get rid of wastewater, which can have chemicals, heavy metals, salt and radioactive material.

Researchers found coffee stops the growth of tumours in women who have already been treated with the drug tamoxifen. Tamoxifen blocks oestrogen from reaching the cancer cells. This means the cancer either grows more slowly or stops growing altogether.

As many as 20% of people suffer with the occasional single mouth ulcer. These are usually shallow and occur on the tongue or inside the lip or cheek. These small painful ulcers usually last no more than ten days and require no treatment. Multiple ongoing mouth ulcers are quite a different issue and certainly warrant further investigation.

The USS Oklahoma capsized after being hit by nine torpedoes on December 7, 1941. Altogether, 429 sailors and Marines onboard were killed. Only 35 were identified in years immediately after. Hundreds were buried as unknowns at cemeteries in Hawaii. In 1950, they were reburied as unknowns at National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific. Move is apparently part of new Pentagon policy on disinterring remains of unknown troops.

They found that Northern Europeans in the Neolithic period initially rejected farming, which was spreading across the continent. The findings show that farming spread in Europe 8,000 years ago. This led to groups of people moving away from foraging and hunting as a means for survival. The findings may also force a complete rethink about how agriculture first arrived in Britain.

Spanish researchers say climate change impacted human migration. Until 1.4 million years ago it was too cold to inhabit southeast Spain. But then the climate warmed to 13°C (55°F) and became more humid. This enabled hominins - our distant ancestors - to move to new regions. But conditions were again 'too dry' for them to move to the region. This enabled them to branch out from Africa into Spain and spread across Europe.

The Optimal case was designed by Israel-based Amited. Sensors in the case monitor the phone's temperature and if it gets too hot, Optimal will cool the device using two built-in micro-fans. And if it gets too cold, Optimal engages its Anti-Freeze mode to gently heat the phone using resistance coils. The case syncs with a smartphone over Bluetooth and constantly analyses the phone's temperature when Auto mode is enabled.

The study was conducted by scientists at Purdue University in Indiana. They were investigating how to reduce bird to aircraft collisions. Research showed that birds responded most to blue lights on planes. But when the plane approached them with its lights off, their response slowed. And they only became more alert when the lights were turned on. This could help capture birds’ attention before an aircraft takes off.

Scientists at Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School have developed a device that clips onto the smartphone. It uses powerful 8MP cameras in combination with microbeads that bind to cancerous cells. When added to a tissue sample, these beads alter the way light passes through it. When clumped together, the beads produce distinctive diffraction patterns. The scientists claim the device can asses 100,000 cells from a single image in around 45 minutes.

Female, named Varvara, swam 14,000 miles (22,500km) from east coast of Russia to breeding grounds off the coast of Mexico, and back. Researchers used satellite-monitoring tags to track three Western North Pacific gray whales from their primary feeding ground off Russia’s Sakhalin Island. Gray whales typically don't feed during migration, which has led researchers to believe Varvara didn't eat during the long journey either.

US researchers say very few of these - often very expensive - weight loss plans have solid evidence to back up their claims. Results suggest only a few programmes have shown their users lose more weight than those not using them. But a handful - including Weight Watchers, the Atkins diet, Jenny Craig and NutriSystem - do appear to be effective, according to long-term studies.

The Maglev train completed a test run on a track in Yamanashi. It beat the previous record of 361mph (580km/h) set in 2003. Another attempt is scheduled for tomorrow and could reach 373mph. Maglev trains use magnets to lift the carriages above the track. This eliminates the need for wheels and therefore any incidence of friction.

Social Services Minister Scott Morrison has announced the end to religious exemption on children’s vaccinations. Parents will no longer be able to access childcare benefits simply by signing a form that says they object to immunisation based on 'personal, philosophical or religious' reasons. Families who do vaccinate their kids are eligible for the $7,500-a-year childcare rebate, $200-a-week childcare benefit and the $726 Family Tax Benefit Part A end of year supplement.

Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system to attach to the ISS. It would be used to shoot down pieces of debris in Earth orbit. The system would have a range of 62 miles (100km) and could target things less than 0.4 inches (1cm) in size. It would then push the junk into Earth’s atmosphere, where it would burn up. The system would be able to detect and target objects up to 0.2 inches (1cm)

University of Manchester researchers have revealed an HD dark matter map. It shows clumps of mystery particles across 0.4 per cent of the sky. The goal is to eventually map 12.5 per cent over five years. Red here shows more dark matter, and blue shows less. The moon is shown top left for scale. And the map will allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe.

Canadian duo Mitchell Moffit and Greg Brown, from Toronto, discuss how being the first, middle, youngest, or an only child affects us. First-born children are expected to be higher academic achievers and more ambitious. Middle-born children tend to be more co-operative and flexible. As a last child, there aren't the high expectations of the first child. As a middle-born, there aren't the relaxed attitude accorded to the last child.

Flakka can be injected, snorted, smoked, swallowed or taken with other substances. It is usually made from the chemical alpha-PVP - the synthetic version of the stimulant cathinone. Once ingested, the drug causes a feeling of euphoria, hallucinations and sometimes psychosis or apparent superhuman strength.

Only people who registered on the site before this date are eligible. A 'blob' of warm water 2,000 miles across is sitting in the Pacific Ocean. Since last June it has extended from Alaska to Mexico. It has been present since 2013 and causing fish to seek shelter elsewhere. And a new University of Washington study says it could be responsible for droughts. It found the water was one to four degrees Celsius above surrounding 'normal' water. This is one to seven degrees Fahrenheit above surrounding 'normal' water. The blob has now extended 1,000 miles (1,600km) offshore, from Alaska up to Mexico.

Extraordinary aerial photographs taken above Whitefish Bay on eastern Lake Superior, Ontario, show some of the freighters lined up across a frozen expanse. They are carrying a variety of goods from Canadian grain to US iron and steel but are being hampered by slabs of ice as big as pick-up trucks. The ships desperately need a path cut through the lake by Canadian and US ice breakers, which have themselves been hampered by the extreme conditions.

Football's anti-discrimination campaigners teamed up with Tempero and Brandwatch. They discovered an abusive message is directed at a Premier League club or one of their players every 2.6 minutes. A total of 134,400 posts were posted on Twitter, Facebook, forums or blogs between August 2014 and March 2015. Liverpool striker Mario Balotelli received the most abuse with more than 8,000 discriminatory messages directed at him. Arsenal's Danny Welbeck received 1,700 messages, more than 60 per cent of which related to sexual orientation.

Encounters with common dolphins off the west of Scotland have doubled. The species were once a rare sight in the Hebrides, preferring warmer waters found further south. But monitoring by Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust teams has seen the number of encounters increase by 68% over the past 12 years. Climate change is causing sea surface temperatures in the Hebrides to rise by around 0.5 °C a decade. Warmer water species appear to be colonising new areas further north or closer to shore.

Nicotine was frequently used as an insecticide until it was banned in 2009. But a surprisingly large number of food crops and plant-derived products still contain very high levels of nicotine. Researchers at the Technical University of Braunschweig, Germany, used peppermint plants, which contain minimal traces of nicotine, in a series of fumigation experiments. They found that plants can take up high concentrations of nicotine from contaminated soils and plumes of smoke.

The albino dolphin is completely white– apart from the quirky tendency to turn pink when it's feeling angry, sad or even embarrassed. The pink tone is a result of the animals thin skin, which means its blood vessels can cause a change in skin tone depending on their emotional state. The rare specimen is believed to be only the second one ever put on display in an aquarium after it was purchased from fishermen last year.

The Modular Robotic Vehicle, or MRV, was developed at Nasa's Johnson Space Center. It relies on control inputs being converted to electrical signals. The vehicle can be driven remotely at up to 70mph. It can also be able to park sideways and spin on the spot.

Archaeologists at Boston University and the University of Bath used computer models to show how much energy Neanderthals would have had from their food without cooking. They found that without fire, a group of Neanderthals would have had less energy - the equivalent 12 reindeer a year - than if they did. This would have meant they lost out when modern humans arrived from Africa.

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission took action against Aldi last year. An investigation revealed it did not disclose a 0.5 percent surcharge placed on transactions made using tap and go contactless payment systems. ASIC also found that ALDI failed to disclose the 0.5 percent surcharge it charges consumers paying by credit card in some of its stores. Aldi told the regulator it would put up signs at the entrance of stores and at registers to notify shoppers of the surcharge.

University of Illinois scientists have created the first 3D simulation of merging black holes in a disk. It shows what happens when two supermassive black holes collide. The simulation was led by Dr Roman Gold, Dr Vasileios Paschalidis, Dr Stuart Shapiro, Dr Milton Ruiz, Dr Zachariah Etienne, and Dr Harald Pfeiffer. It comes after two black holes were found to collide in the Milky Way. The simulation could be used to predict how two supermassive black holes will collide in just seven

Researchers at the University of Alberta examined a pair of fossils found in Mongolia. One is a complete skeleton, while the other is missing the middle and end of its tail. They found that the key differences between the sexes lie in bones near the base of the tail. They believe that the skeletons of male stegosaurus and females had different shaped armoured plates running along their backs. It raises the prospect that the dinosaurs used its giant bony protrusions to attract a mate.

The ancient papyrus was found in Oxyrhynchus, Egypt, in 1896. It contains a medical'recipe' for treating a hangover with the leaves of a shrub called Alexandrian chamaedaphne, or sometimes Alexandrian laurel. The treatment was discovered as part of an ongoing effort to translate the Oxyrhynchus papyrus. The papyrus contains 500,000 documents found in an ancient rubbish tip.

It is now commonly mixed with heroin to make a highly addictive cocktail. It is now being smuggled out of the country and into the UK. Drug muggles risk their lives to smuggle it out of the country.

Biologists at Goethe University Frankfurt, Germany, studied the healing process at a molecular level using electron microscopes. They found skin cells appear to attach to each other using tiny tubes that then pull them together so they interlock like a zip. Researchers hope their findings could help in the development of new treatments for wounds that could speed up this process.

He says that as many as half of young Americans will be so grossly overweight by the end of the decade that the military will be unable to recruit enough qualified soldiers. She sought medical help but doctors were shocked to discover the growth. Known as a brain teratoma, it is very rare and contains hair, teeth and bone. Google has unveiled a new U.S. wireless service that switches between Wi-Fi and cellular networks to curb data use and keep phone bills low. The service, called 'Project Fi,' debuted today, about two months after Google revealed its plans to expand its ever-growing empire into providing wireless connections for smartphones. Google is selling the basic phone service for $20 a month and will only charge customers for the amount of cellular data that they use each month, instead of a flat rate.

Duke University study says that natural variability in surface temperatures over the course of a decade can account for increases and dips in warming rates. But it adds that these so-called 'climate wiggles' could also, in the future, cause our planet to warm up much faster than anticipated. The study compared its results to the most severe emissions scenarios outlined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)

Photographer Graeme Whipps captured this incredible image of the Lyrid meteor shower above Pitcaple in Aberdeenshire yesterday. The annual celestial event has been observed for the last 2,700 years across the globe, but is most visible in the northern hemisphere. The Lyrids are created by debris from comet Thatcher, which takes about 415 years to orbit around the Sun.

Security researchers have found a way to intercept a person's fingerprints. The flaw lies in Android 4.4 and older, but is not present on other models. Hackers can intercept scans from the fingerprint sensor before they reach the encrypted file. This means they can access the phone's kernel and monitor all data sent. This includes data recorded by the fingerprint scanner.
